subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application Server
msgSnippet: ... on ... could ... could ... What would be great would be for you to join the cactus dev mailing list and start submitting ideas/patches/docs/whatever. That
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jon S Bratseth [mailto:Jon.Bratseth@...]
> Sent: 30 October 2002 12:25
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application Server
>
> > > A much simpler approach is to create a test case extension
> > > which
> > > delegates it's execution to a session bean.
> >
> > Why is it simpler? That's exactly Cactus's approach! :-). ATM cactus
> > only provides Filter, Servlet and Jsp extensions but we are working
on
> > providing EJB redirectors (session beans, MDB, EB).
>
> I'm glad to hear that _will_be_ Cactus approach :-)
> I evaluated Cactus before I decided to write ServerTestCase and was
> disappointed it didn't support what I wanted to do.
>
> > I would love to be
> > able to work with you on that if you're interested! It seems we
could
> > easily integrate your solution in Cactus :-)
>
> Yes. I have made some improvements since the junit.org version. I
could
> send
> you the updated source, or I could integrate myself i guess.

What would be great would be for you to join the cactus dev mailing list
and start submitting ideas/patches/docs/whatever. That would help a lot!
I will definitely help you to perform the integration.

If you're interested let's continue this discussion on the cactus-dev
mailing list (see http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/mailinglist.html for
subscribing).

Thanks a lot
-Vincent

>
> --
> Jon S Bratseth
>
> > > There is a package which provides this at
> > > http://www.junit.org/junit/download/ServerTestCase.zip
> >
> > cool. Maybe we can join forces.
> >
> > >
> > > To use it, just deploy the session bean and extends ServerTestCase
> > instead
> > > of TestCase for tests you want to run inside the server.
> >
> > Cool. Again, that's exactly in the same way as Cactus does it.
> >
> > >
> > > The tests will behave like the client/standalone tests, so there
will
> > only
> > > be one test suite to manage and there's no need to re-create all
the
> > > features mentioned below specially for the server-side tests.
> > >
> >
> > Yes, but I don't see how you test your web layer with your solution.
If
> > I remember correctly that was what I was answering to :-). In any
case
> > you don't need to care as Cactus is hiding this for you. EJBs are
> > well-defined components and as such are much easier to unit test
than
> > web components. Actually if you have remote EJBs, you don't even
need to
> > have a session bean redirector, which is even simpler ... :-)
> >
> > > ...Yeah, I know I'm lagging somewhat :-)
> >
> > I don't think so :-)
> >
> > -Vincent
> > >
> > > --
> > > Jon S Bratseth
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: Vincent Massol [mailto:vmassol@...]
> > > > Sent: 13. juli 2002 12:49
> > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > Cc: mrettig@...
> > > > Subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application
Server
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Hi Michael,
> > > >
> > > > <biased>
> > > >
> > > > How different is what you have described from
> > > > http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/1.4/howto_tomcat.html ?
> > > >
> > > > Actually, what you described is exactly JUnitEE
> > > > (http://junitee.sourceforge.net/).
> > > >
> > > > I agree with you, it starts simple and then you need some more
> > features.
> > > > For example, you need to automate the tests as part of a build
(this
> > is
> > > > probably one of the most wanted feature). So you will start to
have
> > a
> > > > client part that calls your URL, parses the XML and display the
> > result.
> > > > All is fine but then you also want to be able to execute the
test
> > from
> > > > any of the existing JUnit integration tools (from IDEs, using
Ant
> > junit
> > > > task, etc). So you will transform your client side into a
TestCase
> > so
> > > > that it can be run by any test runner ...
> > > >
> > > > ... and this is Cactus ! :-)
> > > >
> > > > To summarise :
> > > >
> > > > - yes Cactus can be a simple as what you describe (this is
actually
> > a
> > > > feature of version 1.4, which is not released yet - but soon to
be)
> > > >
> > > > - it allow for more should you need it
> > > >
> > > > - it is documented and there are resources on Cactus : website +
> > books +
> > > > articles
> > > >
> > > > - BTW, Cactus integrates completely with Ant to automated start
up
> > and
> > > > shutdown of application servers
> > > >
> > > > </biased>
> > > >
> > > > Yes, I am the original author of Cactus and thus I am biased :-)
but
> > as
> > > > a user I would always go with existing framework if I find any
that
> > > > perform what I want. For example, I wouldn't dare write my
logging
> > > > framework, MVC controller one, XML to Java mapping one, etc.
> > > >
> > > > In the end it is your choice. I'm just writing this email so
that
> > you
> > > > know Cactus does what you want and that you shouldn't skip it
> > because
> > > > you think it doesn't.
> > > >
> > > > Cheers,
> > > > -Vincent
> > > >
> > > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > > From: Michael Rettig [mailto:mrettig@...]
> > > > > Sent: 13 July 2002 02:45
> > > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > > Subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application
Server
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > From: "Nicholas Lesiecki" <nick@...>
> > > > > > What you describe sounds very similar to Cactus:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Have you looked at it?
> > > > >
> > > > > Yes, and what I'm describing is far simpler than Cactus. There
is
> > no
> > > > > framework to speak of. Just a servlet that knows how to run a
test
> > > > suite
> > > > > and return the results as xml. For instance, you would pass
this
> > URL
> > > > to
> > > > > your browser to run the tests in a remote app server.
> > > > >
> > > > >
http://localhost:8080/junit?classname=com.package.test.TestCase
> > > > >
> > > > > It is very simple, but powerful. Since the test executes
within
> > the
> > > > > servlet container you can access all the facilities of the app
> > server.
> > > > > We've also automated the startup and shutdown of the app
server,
> > so
> > > > the
> > > > > entire test process is completely scripted. This makes it
simple
> > to
> > > > plug
> > > > > the whole process into our cruise control build process.
> > > > >
> > > > > Mike
